ancestors.content:
ME: OK, I need to select some text. Let me just drag over it with my mouse...

COMPUTER: You want the paragraphs before it also, right?

ME: No, just this one sentence. Let me try again. Just this one sentence...

COMPUTER: ...and all text above it.

ME: No, computer! Just this one sentence.

COMPUTER: Look, if you want me to do that, you need to tell me. Just drag the mouse to the correct area.

ME: And what area would that be?

COMPUTER: (Indicates a square one pixel wide)

ancestors.content:
After 3 years of working from home, my wife and I are heading back into the office. Very mixed feelings. Excited to see familiar faces. Terribly sad to be away from our 8mo daughter throughout the day ‚Äî really don‚Äôt want to miss any milestones. Dreading the commute.

I‚Äôm also a completely different person. We have a house, a dog, a daughter. I started game boy modding, finished a cover album, learned to code, and ran more than I ever have. I genuinely have different goals and ambitions

ancestors.content:
Machi Koro

What a sweet little game. Shame I waited so long to try it.

Roll dice to get income from cards and then spend it on better cards until someone buys the last of their mandatory cards. Fine decision about when to flip to throwing two dice instead of one.

My only gripes are that it should be half the price and the box should be quarter the size. Would buy it otherwise.
#boardgames

reblog.content:
"Cistercian Numbers" are incredibly cool

It's a rare numeric system designed by 13th century monks

Each number is a based on a single vertical stick, with patterns you draw in all four quadrants off it -- top right, top left, bottom right, bottom left

A single glyph can represent a number from 1 to 9,999

It's in my recent weekly "Linkfest" newsletter, here: https://buttondown.email/clivethompson/archive/linkfest-3-cisterian-numbers-robots-that-hug-and/

Want to subscribe? Pay-what-you-want here: https://buttondown.email/clivethompson

I call it "The opposite of doomscrolling"

account.note: Writer, musician/songwriter, hobbyist coder. Contributing writer to New York Times Magazine and Wired. Author of "Coders". Blogging at clivethompson.medium.com, archive of writing at www.authory.com/clivethompson #science #technology #coding #software #writing #literature #poetry clive@clivethompson.net

mediaAttachments.description: Marvel Snap screenshot

ancestors.content: As I've been fiddling with decks in #MarvelSnap I've been learning what cards have hidden liabilities. Hobgoblin is a great example: Being down eight points in one lane sounds bad but if you've been playing the spread, it's not fatal. And your opponent just wasted round five trying to drag you down instead of teeing up their strategy.

account.note: He/him, cishet, writer, occasional juggler, non-gatekeepy comics nerd.

ancestors.content: As a rule I've found "pest" decks (i.e. Iceman, Scorpion, Gambit, etc.) are loser decks in #MarvelSnap. Part of this is lousy strategy: Nobody plays these cards in round 5 (hell, I don't play them in round 5!) But another part is that the juice isn't worth the squeeze.

account.note: He/him, cishet, writer, occasional juggler, non-gatekeepy comics nerd.

ancestors.content:
Advice needed...

I'm thinking of putting my entire 250+GB music collection into a private, personal FunkWhale server. I'm on a Mac at home, and I don't like how the Music app is getting less useful. Also, it'd be nice to be able to access my music remotely.

Two ways I can do this...
a) Find some hosting provider that won't charge me an arm and a leg for storage.
b) Learn Docker, learn how to assign a static IP address to my computer, and see if I can do it all from my Mac.

card.title: On Twitter, Oceanographers Show Deep Appreciation for Data-Collection Device
card.description: This is part of a new series of posts that highlight the importance of Earth and space science data and its contributions to society. Posts in this series showcase data facilities and data scientists; explain how Earth and space science data is collected, managed and used; explore what this data tells us about the planet; and delve into the challenges and issues involved in managing and using data. This series is intended to demystify Earth and space science data, and share how this data shapes our understanding of the world.  On Friday, while many people were tracking the progress of the winter storm bearing down on the eastern United States, oceanographers were rummaging through their fieldwork photos for images of CTDs to share on Twitter in honor of #CTDAppreciationDay.

ancestors.content:
@Teuta @wavygk bizarrely, Jan 22 is also my wedding anniversary, when I guess I am also to be appreciated.

(I worked in a team of 4 people called Chris and have been known as CTD for years now. It was my Twitter handle for 14 years also.)

account.note: Came to London from NZ in 1983 for 3 months work... Still in London. Ramble on about books, boardgames & basic nonsense. GameCenter/Twitch: Gleptoportus BGG: Christo

ancestors.content: @Teuta @CTD well you are clearly appreciated! Be careful on oceanographic ships tho as we may put you over the side demanding to know what the water is like ü§ì

account.note: Living in Te Whanganui-a-Tara. An oceanographer w Co-appointment at the Uni of Auckland and NIWA. #Ocean mixing especially beneath Antarctic ice and in fast tidal flows. #Science advocacy with NZ Assoc Scientists. The rest of the time is #guitars #ArtSci #swimming and #ebikes. Thoughts my own. #oceanography #Antarctica #Turbulence #oceans #climate #TransMultiCrossDisciplinary

content: While drawing a tri-weasel (for reasons) it reminded me of my first job. Letters to clients were written long hand on a pad of paper then taken across the hall to the typing pool where it was typed in triplicate using the magic of carbon paper before being returned for correction (with Typ-Ex) and then sent out. No doubt this seemed modern at the time...

ancestors.content:
Browsing the PS4/5 store I can allllmost see why folks might be thinking there's a shortage of great videogames to play.

At the moment, it's pretty easy to lean into "it's COVID and the transition to WFH" but this has been a slow process as Sony have stuck to their guns wrt process and access to the bloody thing. I suspect the virus just hastened things along a tad.

ancestors.content:
This gen is going to be interesting. Not necessarily in a good way but these things rarely are 100%.

I genuinely don't think the old approval model - without the sort of visible and active outreach Shahid's team and their equivalents in other territories we're doing - is going to hold for long and Sony seem to be digging their heels in for the long haul.

ancestors.content:
Gamepass and both the Switch and Steam Deck sell on conveniences and Sony seem to be doubling down on (for want of a better phrase) prestige gaming.

Ignoring that MS's buying spree could, if they were so inclined, mean a chunk of them don't make it to the PS5 at launch or even in good time. Though that's going to be fun to see what happens too. Ignoring that!

Possibly pretty shit news for indies on ps5 that exist outside the ends of "cheap achievement fodder" and "that cost a lot to make".

ancestors.content:
The thing is with this stuff, the rot usually takes a while to filter through in any obvious ways to storefronts without a pandemic happening. Sometimes a year or more because games take their time to make and release. Something decided in 2022 may not majorly filter through until 2024 or something.

So I reckon they could, if little changes soon anyway, get a few more years out of this.

ancestors.content:
But as players are used to an abundance of games now, I'm not sure whether banking on costly games to carry everything is sustainable. But, Sony do also have a lot of money and consoles shifted on their side and in the end, I have no clue here. Wouldn't be the first time I've been wrong!

But that's all where my noggin is at lately.

This gen is going to be weird.

account.note: Came to London from NZ in 1983 for 3 months work... Still in London. Ramble on about books, boardgames & basic nonsense. GameCenter/Twitch: Gleptoportus BGG: Christo

ancestors.content:
@CTD SteamDeck takes an USB C input using DP. I have an adapter as part of acheap USB-C hub and it works just fine.

But I also have an old HP travel adapter/hub thing, and it doesn't work at all. Might be that it depends on the chipset used; or adapters 5+ years old don't use DP or something.

But they're cheap; get one and try it.

reblog.content:
This website provides the full back archive of BYTE magazine, all 23 years of it from 1975 to to 1998. It's a treasure trove of vintage tech and nostalgia, not even Archive.org carries all the issues.

The site actually focuses on old Apple magazines, but has also PC magazines and other resources on the history of microcomputing.

https://vintageapple.org/byte

#retrocomputing #magazines

ancestors.content:
Today just feels a bit smeg. It's January, it's grey and miserable out, sheep are all indoors, I don't feel properly grooved in to my next project yet, I dropped the bread in the mud getting out of the car just now, Keir Starmer still talks about making Brexit "work" for fuck's sake, it gets dark too fucking early, everything's just grey and smeg.

I should've stayed in bed with the plushies and fur. üêÇ

At least there's still Mrs Jones and the parsnips I guess.

ancestors.content:
I deeply loved this game, an absolutely perfect synthesis of story, visual and typographic design, scholarly research, and interactive gameplay. It ends with a long bibliography. It‚Äôs one of those works of art that makes me wish I could‚Äôve been involved in its making.

I typically don‚Äôt care for point-and-click adventures‚Äîthe slow pacing and flat art style usually doesn‚Äôt work for me‚Äîbut here those elements are integral to the story. Winter, around Christmastime, is the ideal time to play it.

(In an alternate reality you could play it on the web, but that‚Äôs not how the history of gamedev went, so I implore you to borrow an old Windows laptop from a friend if you don‚Äôt own an XBox or PC.)

#pentiment #NarrativeGames

https://pentiment.obsidian.net/

ancestors.content:
Village (4p, 2h)
Played the 2012 Spiel des Jahres Kennerspiel des Jahres Winner last night for the first time. The Kennerspiel is accurate predictor for my taste.
I like this softer worker placement, where missing your action doesn't feel like agony.
It's a little confusing at first, but overall not too complicated and not too long.

card.title: Statement on the Genocidal Nature of the Gender Critical Movement‚Äôs Ideology and Practice
card.description:
November 29, 2022

The Lemkin Institute for Genocide Prevention voices its concern over the growing number of laws introduced in the United States that target transgender individuals and the transgender community. Anti-trans hostility in the US has become a staple of the Republican Party‚Äôs election strategy and is clearly being used to stoke voters‚Äô fears of a changing world by raising the specter of a malevolent polluting force tied to liberalism, cosmopolitanism, and democracy. The Lemkin Institute believes that the so-called ‚Äúgender critical movement‚Äù that is behind these laws is a fascist movement furthering a specifically genocidal ideology that seeks the complete eradication of trans identity from the world.

reblog.content:
Unfortunately I have to stop actively working on #Metatext for a while due to health issues. I really wish I could implement Mastodon 4 features and squash every bug, but it's not possible for me to do so right now.

I know the app has become important to a lot people, so I'm open to a new maintainer who can carry on its values of privacy and accessibility taking it over if there's interest and a fit. Email info@metabolist.org if you (or your organization) are interested

card.title: Write to your MP to help stop the Online Safety Bill
card.description: The Online Safety Bill is set to return to Parliament on 5th December. Time is running out to secure the privacy of your personal messages. ‚ùå Private chat platforms, such as WhatsApp, Signal, Facebook Messenger and Telegram, will also fall under the bill‚Äôs mandate. ‚ùå Under a recent amendment to the bill, they will have to scan for government-specified forms of illegal content using Home Office-approved systems. It is a deeply intrusive form of surveillance that will compromise the end-to-end encryption that currently keeps our chats confidential and secure.

account.note:
Scarfolk is a town in North West England that did not progress beyond 1979. Instead, the entire decade of the 1970s loops ad infinitum. Here in Scarfolk, pagan rituals blend seamlessly with science; hauntology is a compulsory subject at school, and everyone must be in bed by 8pm because they are perpetually running a slight fever. "Visit Scarfolk today. Our number one priority is keeping rabies at bay."

For more information please re-read.

account.note:
I'm a #writer, #poet, #researcher, #historian. I enjoy #reading, #nature and #architecture. My work can be found on #Medium, #unsplash, and my website.

I started as a #Research #Historian when was 16. My niche is #19thcentury #society and #culture. I'm also a #genealogist and trained in #museum and #archive work.

I have #chronicillness, #chronicpain, and #migraines, among other #neurological #diseases. I'm a #heller, #spn #thewinchesters, Sci Fi/Fanstasy movies, and mystery lover.

card.title: ‚ÄéWhen Did I‚Ä¶?
card.description: ‚ÄéWhen did you last change your sheets? Did you take your multivitamin today? When Did I‚Ä¶? lets you track when you do things so you can answer these questions and more. Choose from our suggested Actions or add your own so you can keep on top of things you‚Äôve done. From things you do every day, to thin‚Ä¶

ancestors.content:
Can someone recommend an app for logging any kind of event and then getting some statistics out of it? Example events:

- Walked the dog.
- Drank a cup of coffee.
- Felt a sore knee.
- Used dental floss.
- Saw a full moon.

After logging events over a period of time the app should be able to answer questions like "How often do I feel a sore knee?".

I don't want to use Shortcuts, Airtable, or similar. I'm looking for an all-in-one solution. My backup plan is using a calendar.

ancestors.content:
Hello Mastodon!

Three months ago I left Twitter and have been without a text-based social media in my life.

Recently I have realised that I miss having a place to share what I‚Äôm working on and what I‚Äôm excited about

I‚Äôm trying to make more healthy choices about how much I use social media, but I want to be able to have this outlet as well as my podcasts.

So from now, you can find me here!

Thank you for bearing with me, and being interested in what I‚Äôm doing.

I appreciate you.

ü§ì‚úåÔ∏è

ancestors.content:
Can someone recommend an app for logging any kind of event and then getting some statistics out of it? Example events:

- Walked the dog.
- Drank a cup of coffee.
- Felt a sore knee.
- Used dental floss.
- Saw a full moon.

After logging events over a period of time the app should be able to answer questions like "How often do I feel a sore knee?".

I don't want to use Shortcuts, Airtable, or similar. I'm looking for an all-in-one solution. My backup plan is using a calendar.

card.title: Etrian Odyssey Origins Collection announced for Switch, PC - Gematsu
card.description: ATLUS has announced dungeon RPG collection Etrian Odyssey Origins Collection for Switch and PC (I HD, II HD, III HD). It will launch on June 1 worldwide. Get the details below.

ancestors.content:
Apart from Resident Evil 4 and Star Wars Jedi: Survivor, it looks like 2023 might see the Switch being my primary console for a while. I'm looking forward to playing Advance Wars 1+2, Metroid Prime Remastered, Octopath Traveller II, Fire Emblem Engage, Triangle Strategy, Mario + Rabbids Spart of Hope, and Tactics Ogre: Reborn. And the GB and GBA games, particularly Golden Sun and the Zelda games.

People think getting old sucks but disposable income for gaming is a big plus.

People think getting old sucks but disposable income for gaming is a big plus.
